LVI. ¹ Ex omni copia] Copia, even in the singular number, is sometimes used to signify forces or an army. Tacit. An. ii. 52, Ma- zippa levi eum copia, incendia et eaedeS, et terrorem circumferret. Virg. AEneid. ii. 564, Respicio, et quae sit me circum copia lustra—M.

Ex omni copiti] Mair forgot to quote himself on Caesar de Bell. Gall. lib. 1, c. 48, where he adduces de Bell. Afr. c. 38, Pedestrem copiam in secunda acie constituunt ; and beneath, in this chapter, Ex omni copia circiter pars quarta erat, δια-Ο.

² cohortes, pro numero militum] A legion consisted of ten cohorte, each cohort of three manipuli, and each manipulus of two centuriae. And this was constantly the form in the Roman armies, whether the legion consisted of a great number or a small : for sometimes a legion had in it 6000 men, and then each centuria had 100, and each mani- pulus 200, and each cohort 600. Sometimes the legion consisted only of 30003 and then each centuria had 50, each manipulus 100, and each cohort 300. Sometimes a legion was made of 4000, sometimes of 5000, and the number of men in each centuria, manipuluS, and 00- hort, varied accordingly.—M.

³ AEqualiter distribuerat] Equally betwixt the two legions, sothat each might consist of the same number of men-M.

⁴ Numero hominum] Such a number as usually went to a legion in the Roman armies at that time.--M.
